NO reduction reaction (NORR) is not only an attractive method for sustainable ammonia (NH3) production, but also a green method to eliminate the harmful gas NO. But a few NORR catalysts have been explored at present, and it remains a great challenge to explore efficient catalysts for the conversion of NO to NH3. Here, based on first-principles calculations, we proposed a g-C3N4-based biatomic catalyst (BAC) as a promising candidate for NORR. We systematically studied the activation and conversion of NO on g-C3N4 loaded with double 3d transition metal (TM), 3d TM and non-metallic atom, double non-metallic atoms. After screening for structural stability, adsorption of NO, catalytic activity of NORR and selectivity of NH3, it is found that 2Mn@g-C3N4 is a stable NORR catalyst with high catalytic activity and selectivity. And then studied the charge variation to understand in depth the mechanism of its high catalytic activity. In addition, we also verified that all the structures have good thermodynamic stability, and g-C3N4 can be used as a suitable substrate for diatomic catalyst. This study not only provides an idea for screening BACs for the synthesis of NH3 by NO reduction, but also shows that BACs has great potential of NORR and contributes to the application of BACs in other electrochemical reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords First-principles calculation NO electrocatalytic reduction Biatom catalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Nowadays, people 's great demand for energy makes the environmental pollution caused by industrial waste gas and automobile exhaust gradually become the focus of the world's attention. Among them, NO, one of the harmful gases due to its large emissions will lead to acid rain, ozone depletion and a series of problems, caused serious harm to human health and aggravated environmental pollution [1,2]. Therefore, it's imperative to eliminate NO gas molecules from the atmosphere. At present, there are two main methods for treating nitrogen oxides in industry: selective non-catalytic reduction method and selective catalytic method. Selective non-catalytic reduction method mainly includes wet absorption method, solid adsorption method and so on, and selective catalytic reduction method usually uses NH3 or H2 as reducing agent to reduce NO to N2 at a temperature above 300 °C. However, these methods generally exist some problems, such as large equipment, large mount of energy, high cost caused by consumption of high-value reducing agents, secondary pollution and so on, it is not ideal technologies and methods. Exploring a green and suitable method for eliminating NO is one of the most active problems in catalytic chemistry field. Additionally, NH3 is one of the most important raw materials to synthesize chemistry and produce fertilizer in chemical, scientific research and others fields [3,4]. Conventional industry NH3 synthesis is based on the Haber-Bosch process under high temperatures and high pressure, which will not only consume large mount of natural energy and human resources, but also lead to serious environmental pollution [5–7]. Inspired by biological fixation of nitrogen in nature, electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) can be used as an effective alternative method to the Haber-Bosch process, namely uses electric energy to reduce N2 to NH3 by adding some chemicals to the electrolyte solution [8,9]. Though N2 is the most abundant gas and NRR process can be proceeding through wind energy and solar energy, it has attracted the attention of many researchers [10–16]. Non-metallic substrates, which usually have the advantages of low cost and long durability, are widely used in catalytic reactions. For example, C2N has been considered a potential candidate for anchoring order atoms. Some researchers have anchored non-metallic atoms or metal atoms on its surface and studied its NRR catalytic performance. The results showed that all of them had good catalytic performanc [17,18]. Based on density functional theory, Wu et al. systematically studied the catalytic performance of NRR anchored by transition metal atoms on the surface of ternary B3C2P2 monolayer and B/PCx monolayer respectively, and screened the ideal catalysts [19,20]. However, N2 molecule is difficult to adsorb and activate because of the chemical inertness and non-polar properties, and the solubility of N2 in the water is also low, leading to low NH3 yield and faraday efficiency. Therefore, industry synthesis of NH3 by electrochemical NRR still is a great challenge. Similarly, electrochemical NO reduction reaction (NORR) is a promising method to solve the problem of eliminating NO and NH3 synthesis simultaneously. The strength of NO bond is much smaller than that of NN bond, and NO has great polarity. Therefore, NO is more active than polar N2. Compared NRR, electrocatalytic reduction NO to produce NH3 is easier on thermodynamics and kinetics. It is worth noting that NORR process faces challenges and problems in exploring efficient and sustainable electrocatalysts to promote the reaction rate and product selectivity. For this purpose, NORR catalysts with better catalytic activity and selectivity are also continually explored and designed [21]. Up to now, researchers have found that metal catalysts generally exist excellent catalytic activity, such as Pt, Au, Cu and so on [22–25]. But the metal catalysts have lower atomic utilization rate and high cost, which is unfavorable practical application. However, single atom catalysts (SAC) can great improve the atomic utilization and have better durability, and low cost, so it is used widely to resolve the problems of metal catalysts. From the view of electrocatalytic reaction, many two-dimensional materials have been verified as substrates for promising SAC, such as BN, BP, B2C, graphene, C2N, C3N4 and so on [26–32]. It is one of the necessary ways to develop new and efficient NORR catalysts and promote NORR technology. Meanwhile, the biatom catalysts (BAC) derived from the SAC have gradually come into public view because of their high atomic utilization rate and special catalytic activity. BAC can improve the catalytic performance by utilizing interatomic synergies. At present, a lot of progress has been obtained, such as hydrogen evolution (HER) [33], oxide reduction reaction [34], NRR [35–38], NORR [39], CO oxidation reaction [40] and CO2 reduction reaction [41]. As we all know, like graphene materials have been widely used due to their excellent properties, such as BN, phosphorene, C3N4 [42,43]. But as far as we know, BN monolayer has a larger band gap of 4.71 eV [44], which reduces the conductivity of electrocatalysts and hinders the carrier migration during the electrocatalytic reduction reaction. And phosphorene can degradated spontaneously and also hinders practical application. However, C3N4 have a lower band gap and is relatively stable compared with above two materials, it has been studied in the field of electrocatalysts. Moreover, C3N4 has evenly distributed holes, which can anchored the atom firmly, inhibit the diffusion and aggregation of atoms, and provide the rich N coordinate for atoms. Inspired by Zang's study of biatom regulation on C2N surface and NORR catalytic performance [45], we guessed that the use of C3N4 natural holes regulation is also expected to be a suitable electrocatalyst substrate for NORR. In this work, we utilizated density functional theory to study the NORR performance on the biatom (2Cr, 2Mn, 2Fe, 2Co, 2Ni, CrB, FeB, CoB, NiB, 2B) loaded the monolayer g-C3N4 holes. We successfully explored a sTable 2Mn@g-C3N4 BAC with excellent catalytic activity and selectivity by first-principles calculation. Our work promotes the process of designing and exploring conversion of NO-to-NH3 and has guiding significance for the exploration of high-performance BAC. Computational details In this work, spin density functional theory (DFT) is calculated using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP). The interaction between electrons and ions is depicted by the Project enhanced wave (PAW) method [46], and the exchange correlation is depicted by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of the Perdew-Burke Enzerhor (PBE) functional [47]. We use a pristine 2 × 2 × 1 C3N4 surface supercell (containing 48 atoms) for decoration and calculation. A cutoff energy was set as 500 eV. A vacuum layer was set as 20 Å to avoid periodic repetition effects. The Brillouin zone was sampled using a 3 × 3 × 1 k-point grid mesh centered for geometry optimization, and 5 × 5 × 1 k-point grid mesh centered for electronic properties calculation. The energy convergence criteria was set as 1.0 × 10 − 5 eV/atom and mechanical convergence criteria was set as 0.02 eV/Å for all structural optimization. The van der Waals interactions was calculated and correct by using the empirical correction in Grimme's method (DFT-D3). The calculated bind energy (E b) can be used to evaluate the stability of biatom doped g-C3N4 surface by following the Eq. (1): (1) E b = E t o t a l − E p r i s t i n e − 2 E d o p e − d a t o m Where E total, E pristine are energy of biatom doped g-C3N4 surface and pristine g-C3N4 surface, and E doped-atom is the energy of doped atom. The adsorption energy (E ads) gas molecules on the surface can be calculated according to the Eq. (2): (2) E a d s = E t o t a l − E s u r f a c e − E a d s o r b a t e s Where the E total, E surface and E adsorbates are energy of X@g-C3N4 and adsorbates, g-C3N4 and adsorbates, respectively. X is 2Cr, 2Mn, 2Fe, 2Co, 2Ni, CrB, FeB, CoB, NiB and 2B, respectively. In order to understand the electron distribution of adsorbed gas molecules, we calculate the charge density difference (Δρ), and the calculation formula follows the Eq. (3): (3) Δ ρ = Δ ρ NO − X @ g − C 3 N 4 − Δ ρ NO − Δ ρ surface Where the Δρ is obtained by the difference among the NO molecule adsorbed on the X@g-C3N4 surface (ΔρNO-X@g-C3N4), free NO (ΔρNO) molecule and the X@g-C3N4 surface (Δρsubstrate). The value of Gibbs free energy variation (∆G) at every step in the reduction pathways is calculated to amend the zero-point energy and entropy of the DFT [48,49]. And the calculation formula following the Eq. (4): (4) Δ G = Δ E + Δ Z P E − T Δ S + Δ G U + Δ G p H ΔE get from first-principles calculations, ∆ZPE is zero-point energy, T is 298.15 K and ∆S is entropy change. ΔGU = -eU is the free energy contribution caused by electrode potential U. ΔGpH = kBT × ln10 × pH, where kB is the Boltzmann constant, and pH was set at 0 in this study. Therefore, ΔGpH is 0 in this work. In order to evaluate the thermodynamic stability of the structure, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations were performed. Results and discussion Geometric structure of catalyst model Based on the previous research, many studies have been conducted on C3N4, for example: single transition metal atoms decorated g-C3N4 for the NORR [50], single atom on defective g-C3N4 for ORR [43], C atom decorated hole of g-C3N4 for the NRR [51]. Inspired by previous research, we first considered the structural stability of double 3d transition metals (Ti-Cu), double non-metallic atoms (B, C, O, P), transition metals (Ti-Cu) and B atom loaded at g-C3N4 holes, respectively. After the optimization of the geometric structure, some of the structures have serious distortion. Therefore, in the following work, we only conduct further research on 10 kinds of structures (2Cr, 2Mn, 2Fe, 2Co, 2Ni, CrB, FeB, CoB, NiB and 2B@g-C3N4). As shown in Fig. 1 a, three types of geometry are shown, and the optimized structures for each are listed in Fig. S1 (Supporting information). In order to more clearly identify efficient catalysts, we developed a five-step screening strategy: stability, NOH/HNO adsorption capacity, catalytic activity of NORR, competitive reaction of NORR and HER, selectivity, as shown in Fig. 1b. In order to further verify the stability of the 10 candidates, we firstly calculated their bind energies (Eb ) followed Eq. (1) respectively, and the results are shown in Fig. 1c. It can be seen that all Eb are negative, indicating that a stable load is available in the g-C3N4 hole. Adsorption of NO For the NORR, the initial and crucial step is the NO adsorption. Therefore, we will first examine three potential configurations for NO adsorption: side-on, N-end, and O-end. The Eads of NO on ten X@g-C3N4 candidates were calculated in various ways, and the results are presented in Fig. 1d and Table S1. The Eads is calculated according to Eq. (2). Our calculations indicate that the interaction between 10 X@g-C3N4 and NO is a chemisorption process. Although the Eads of NO is lower in N-end adsorption on 2Mn@g-C3N4, its optimized structure is the same as that of side-on adsorption, and combined with charge transfer (Table S1, Supporting information), subsequent studies select side-on adsorption configuration as the preferred method for NO adsorbed on 2Mn@g-C3N4. According to the calculation results of Eads , charge transfer of NO and relaxation structure, it can be found that NO is easily adsorbed on 2Cr@g-C3N4, 2Mn@g-C3N4, CrB@g-C3N4, 2B@g-C3N4 through the side-on configuration, and 2Fe@g-C3N4 through the O-end configuration, while the N-end configuration prefers 2Co@g-C3N4, 2Ni@g-C3N4, FeB@g-C3N4, CoB@g-C3N4, NiB@g-C3N4, and 2B@g-C3N4. In order to further investigate the interaction between NO and substrate, projected densities of states (PDOS), Charge density differences (CDD) and projected crystal orbital Hamilton population (pCOHP) before and after X@g-C3N4 adsorption of NO were analyzed (Fig. 2 ). As shown in Fig. 2a–c, the d orbital of transition metal plays a major role in the adsorption and activation of NO. When NO is adsorbed on 2Mn@g-C3N4 surface with side on pattern, occupied 3d orbitals of Mn atoms transfer electrons to the empty π* orbitals of NO to form d-π* orbitals. At the same time, the occupied σ orbital of NO is hybridized with the Mn-3d orbital to form the d-σ orbital. This can be attributed to the electronic "donation-back donation" mechanism, as shown in Fig. 2d. Similar characteristics can be seen when NO is adsorbed on 2Ni@g-C3N4 surface with N-end on pattern. PDOS of other adsorbed structures are placed in Fig. S2 (Supporting information). It can also be seen from the CDD in Fig. 2d that 0.71 e are transferred from the substrate to NO molecule, and the calculation formula of CDD is shown in equation S1 (Supporting information). Analysis of pCOHP can also deepen the understanding of NO activation mechanism. The negative value represents anti-bonding states and positive region represents the bonding states [52,53]. As can be seen from Fig. 2e–g, there are all antibonding states near the Fermi level, indicating that the NO bond is weakened and NO is activated after adsorption. In addition, it is worth noting that the larger the negative value of ICOHP, the stronger the NO interaction. The ICOHP values of 2Mn@g-C3N4 and 2Ni@g-C3N4 varied from −19.29 to −13.75 and −16.66, respectively, providing evidence for the effective adsorption and activation of NO. In Fig. 2h, the substrate transfers 0.46 electrons to NO molecule, which also reflects the electronic "donation-back donation" mechanism [54]. Such an analysis can be seen in the other X@g-C3N4 as well (Figs. S3 and S4, Supporting information). NORR activity Then, we considered the NORR catalytic activity of the screened X@g-C3N4 surface through different NORR pathways, including O-distal, O-alternating, N-distal and N-alternating. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the conversion of NO to NH3 requires a five-step hydrogenation process [55]. To determine which pathway is the most advantageous, all possible intermediates on X@g-C3N4 are taken into account and the free energy of all reaction steps is calculated. In addition, the limiting potentials (UL) of the most favorable NORR process for all candidates are listed in Fig. 3b. The limiting potential is usually used to evaluate catalytic activity, and is commonly calculated by UL = -ΔGmax/e, where ΔGmax is potential determining step (PDS), namely, the step in the whole catalytic reduction process that requires overcoming the maximum energy. The free energy variation (ΔG) is calculated by the equation S2 (Supporting information). It can be seen from the above results that 2Mn and 2Ni@g-C3N4 exhibit excellent catalytic activity and their UL values are −0.33 and −0.46 V, respectively. In addition, when NO gas molecule is adsorbed on 2B@g-C3N4 with side-on mode, the UL is −0.51 V, and the UL of NiB@g-C3N4 is −0.53 V, both showed general catalytic activity. However, the UL of NO adsorbed on 2B@g-C3N4 with N-end on mode is −0.60 V, and the remaining 2Cr, 2Fe, 2Co, CrB, FeB, and CoB@g-C3N4 have poor catalytic activity with UL values of −1.41, −0.77, −0.62, −0.82, −0.94 and −0.61 V, respectively, which need to overcome large energy barriers during the reaction. NORR free energy diagram for all considered pathways on the X@g-C3N4 are plotted in Figs. 3c and d and S4 (Supporting information) to more clearly show the most advantageous pathway and corresponding UL. The geometric structure of the intermediate in the NORR process is shown in Figs. S6–S16 (Supporting information). As depicted in Fig. 3c, NORR on 2Mn@g-C3N4 is more inclined to the O-alternating pathway. The optimal reaction intermediates include *NOH, *HNOH, *H2NOH, *NH2 and *NH3, and PDS is the last hydrogenation step with UL of −0.33 V. Similarly, as shown in Fig. 3d, the O-alternating pathway is also the favor pathway for NO catalytic reduction on 2Ni@g-C3N4 with intermediates including *NOH, *HNOH, *NH, *NH2 and *NH3. Hydrogenation of *NH2 to *NH3 remains PDS with a UL of −0.46 V. In all candidates, PDS is usually the first and final hydrogenation process. Based on the screening strategies illustrated in Fig. 1b, FeB, CoB and NiB@g-C3N4 fail to satisfy the criteria for excellent catalysts due to their ΔG*HNO and ΔG*NOH values as shown in Fig. S4. For 2B@g-C3N4-end on system, PDS is the third hydrogenation with the UL value of −0.60 V, and NORR prefers the O-distal pathway. The PDS of 2Cr, 2Fe, 2Co and CrB@g-C3N4 are all the last step of hydrogenation through O-alternating, N-alternating, N-distal and N-distal pathway, respectively. In particular, hydrogenation of *NO leads to the formation of *HNO and *NOH intermediates in the NORR process on 2B@g-C3N4-side on system. While the formation of *NOH is more exothermic than that of *HNO, the generation of *N or *HNOH from *NOH requires a higher activation energy barrier. However, continuing hydrogenation by HNO is an exothermic process. Therefore, after careful comparison of the free energy of each intermediate, it was determined that the 2B@g-C3N4-side on system exhibits a greater inclination towards the N-distal path. In addition, we theoretically propose that the optimal pathway for NORR on 2B@g-C3N4-side on system involves sequential formation of intermediates: *HNO, *H2NO, *H2NOH, *NH2 and *NH3. Therefore, the PDS of the remaining five candidates is the final hydrogenation process. It is noteworthy that the 2Mn@g-C3N4 exhibits a lower UL (−0.33 V) than its SAC Cu@g-C3N4 (−0.371 V), indicating higher catalytic activity [50]. NH3 selectivity For NORR, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is the most competitive reaction, and effectively inhibiting HER is an important method to improve NH3 selectivity [56–58]. The Gibbs free energy diagram of HER on different biatom is shown in Fig. 4 a. It can be seen that the adsorption of H on all catalysts is a descending process, that is, an exothermic process, indicating that H can be independently adsorbed on the surface of the catalysts. Fig. 4b compares the UL of NORR and HER, where the catalyst above the short dash line indicates that the UL of NORR is higher than HER's, indicating that NORR has a higher selectivity than HER. Therefore, all catalysts except 2Cr, 2Co and FeB@g-C3N4 can effectively inhibit HER. It is worth noting that 2Mn and 2Nig-C3N4 are considered to be excellent NORR catalysts because of their high catalytic activity and high selectivity. From previous studies [18,25,34], NORR process may produce by-products N2O and N2 through the formation of NO dimer, which will compete with the synthesis of NH3. Therefore, we investigated three possible pathways for NO-to-N2 and NO-to-N2O respectively (2O-downward side, 2N-downward side, and 1O-downward end), as shown in Fig. 5 a. The free energies for generating N2 and N2O on 2Mn@g-C3N4 and 2Ni@g-C3N4 are shown in Fig. 5b and c, respectively, and the intermediate geometric structure is shown in Figs. S17 and S18. On 2Mn@g-C3N4, it is difficult to form NO dimer on 2N-downward side adsorption after full optimization. Therefore, we will not study this pathway. As can be seen from Fig. 5b, it is quite difficult step from *OH to *H2O in the process of generating N2, resulting in UL(N2) being −1.30 V, in the process of generating N2O, from *O+OH to *O is PDS, and UL(N2O) is −4.96 V. NO dimers can be formed on 2Ni@g-C3N4 only 1O-downward end adsorption, and according to their fully optimized geometry, the No-to-N2 pathway is more favorable with UL(N2) of 0.09 V. Therefore, from a thermodynamic point of view, the synthesis of NH3 is more favorable on 2Mn@g-C3N4, while the formation of N2 and N2O is more favorable on 2Ni@g-C3N4. Mechanisms of high NORR activity To further understand the excellent NORR catalytic activity of 2Mn and 2Ni@g-C3N4, we investigated the charge variation at each elementary step of reaction process (Fig. 6 ). Based on previous research, we divide catalysts and adsorption species into three moieties, including moiety 1 (g-C3N4), moiety 2 (2TM and its surrounding N atoms) and moiety 3 (adsorbed NxOHy species) [35,44,50,59]. The calculated charge variation is the difference between the current step of each part and the original step. Moiety 2 of the 2Mn@g-C3N4 system is 2Mn and its surrounding 6 N atoms (Fig. 6a). As shown in Fig. 5b, for the first step, NO is adsorbed on 2Mn@g-C3N4 by side-on mode, NO molecule and Mn2N6 acquire 0.71 and 5.10 electrons, respectively. However, Mn2N6 transfers 1.30 electrons to *NOH species and g-C3N4 during the first step of hydrogenation. According to our calculation, moiety 1 is always an electron donor in the reduction pathway, providing electrons to NxOHy adsorbed species and Mn2N6, except in the first step of hydrogenation. In addition, moiety 2 of the 2Ni@g-C3N4 system is Ni and its surrounding 4 N atoms (Fig. 6c). Similarly, in the reduction path, three moieties show evident charge variation. In NORR, substrate g-C3N4 always acts as an electron donor, while Ni2N4 acts as a transport medium between moiety 1 and moiety 3 to transfer electrons. Therefore, the electron contribution capacity of g-C3N4 plays an important role in the subsequent activation and reduction of NO. The stability of biatom catalysts is a common problem, so we performed AIMD simulations at 500 K for all structures to evaluate their thermodynamic stability (Figs. 7 and S19). The total period is 10 ps and the time step is 2 fs. According to the results, it can be observed that both energy and temperature oscillate around the equilibrium state. In addition, compared with the structure before simulation, X@g-C3N4 can still maintain a good planar structure, and the doped atoms can stably stay in the holes, indicating that it has higher thermodynamic stability. The stability of electrocatalyst in aqueous environment is very important for its practical application. In order to evaluate the electrochemical stability of 2Mn@g-C3N4 with the best catalytic activity, molecular dynamics simulations were performed at 500 K in a water environment. The evolution of energy and temperature simulations over simulation time is shown in Fig. S20. After 10 ps, the structure of 2Mn@g-C3N4 remained stable without significant distortion at 500 K temperature. In addition, we also calculated that the adsorption energy of H2O on 2Mn@g-C3N4 is −2.22 eV, which is smaller than that of NO (−2.99 eV), indicating that 2Mn@g-C3N4 is more likely to trap NO molecules. Therefore, g-C3N4 is a suitable substrate material for biatom catalysts. Conclusion In conclusion, we systematically studied the catalytic activity and selectivity of various BACs anchoring on g-C3N4 surface as NORR catalysts based on density functional theory. Our results show that BAC anchoring on g-C3N4 surfaces has excellent thermodynamic stability, and NO can be fully activated at X@g-C3N4. In particular, 2Mn@g-C3N4 has high catalytic activity due to its low limiting potential (0.33 V), and has better selectivity than HER, which is comparable to the excellent NORR catalysts reported by predecessors, such as PC6 and Pt (100) [23,55,60]. Therefore, it becomes an efficient NORR catalyst. In addition, AIMD simulations show that all structures have good thermodynamic stability, which indicates that loading diatoms on g-C3N4 can be used as a suitable biatom catalyst. This study not only provides an example of the conversion of BAC for NO to NH3, but also provides ideas for the design of reasonably efficient NORR catalysts, which may help advance the research of other electrocatalytic reactions. coredata.dc:description: NO reduction reaction (NORR) is not only an attractive method for sustainable ammonia (NH3) production, but also a green method to eliminate the harmful gas NO. But a few NORR catalysts have been explored at present, and it remains a great challenge to explore efficient catalysts for the conversion of NO to NH3. Here, based on first-principles calculations, we proposed a g-C3N4-based biatomic catalyst (BAC) as a promising candidate for NORR. We systematically studied the activation and conversion of NO on g-C3N4 loaded with double 3d transition metal (TM), 3d TM and non-metallic atom, double non-metallic atoms. After screening for structural stability, adsorption of NO, catalytic activity of NORR and selectivity of NH3, it is found that 2Mn@g-C3N4 is a stable NORR catalyst with high catalytic activity and selectivity. And then studied the charge variation to understand in depth the mechanism of its high catalytic activity. In addition, we also verified that all the structures have good thermodynamic stability, and g-C3N4 can be used as a suitable substrate for diatomic catalyst. This study not only provides an idea for screening BACs for the synthesis of NH3 by NO reduction, but also shows that BACs has great potential of NORR and contributes to the application of BACs in other electrochemical reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient biatom catalyst for nitric oxide reduction based on monolayer carbon nitride
